{{Infobox musical artist | name = Gary Primich | image = Gary Primich.jpg | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Gary Alan Primich | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1958|4|20|mf=y}}
[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|2007|9|23|1958|4|20|mf=y}}
[[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], United States | origin = | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[harmonica]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], [[contemporary blues]] | occupation = [[List of harmonicists|Harmonicist]], [[singing|singer]], [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Mid 1980s–2007 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Gary Primich''' (April 20, 1958 – September 23, 2007) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player, [[singing|singer]], [[guitarist]] and [[songwriter]]. He is best known for his 1995 album, ''Mr. Freeze''. ==Biography== '''Gary Alan Primich''' was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], but grew up in nearby [[Hobart, Indiana|Hobart]], [[Indiana]], where he attended [[Hobart High School (Indiana)|Hobart High School]]. In 1984, after he graduated with a [[Bachelor's degree]] from [[Indiana University]], Primich relocated to [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]].{{cite web|author=Richard Skelly |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gary-primich-mn0000800271/biography |title=Gary Primich | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} While working at the [[University of Texas at Austin|University of Texas]], he started playing along with other musicians in local [[nightclub|clubs]]. In 1987, he met [[Jimmy Carl Black]], and they formed the Mannish Boys. Their debut [[album]], ''A L'il Dab'll Do Ya'' was issued on the Amazing Records [[record label|label]], and although Black then left the band, Primich stayed with the Mannish Boys for another album, ''Satellite Rock''. In 1991 Primich released his eponymous [[solo (music)|solo]] debut album, and ''My Pleasure'' followed the next year. Amazing Records then folded, and Primich was contracted to the [[Flying Fish Records]] label releasing ''Travelin' Mood'' (1994) and ''Mr. Freeze'' (1995). ''Mr. Freeze'' was named as one of the twenty best blues albums of the 1990s by the Chicago [[newspaper]], ''[[New City Chicago|New City]]''.{{cite web|url=http://themusicsover.wordpress.com/2009/09/ |title=2009 » September The Music's Over |publisher=Themusicsover.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Constant touring allowed Primich to expand his fan base, and by 2000, he had a [[recording contract]] with the Texas Music Group. He issued ''Dog House Music'' (2002) and then ''Ridin' the Darkhorse'' (2006). Primich also recorded with [[Steve James (blues musician)|Steve James]], [[Omar & the Howlers]], [[John "Juke" Logan]], [[Marcia Ball]], [[Ruthie Foster]], [[Mike Morgan (blues musician)|Mike Morgan and the Crawl]], [[Nick Curran (musician)|Nick Curran]], [[Doyle Bramhall]] and [[Jimmie Vaughan]].{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2007b.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2007 July To December |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} In addition to his performance albums, in 1985 Primich released an instructional double [[Compact disc|CD]], ''Blues Harmonica: The Blues And Beyond''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tiscali.co.uk/music/biography/artist/gary-primich/biography/17155 |title=Gary Primich Biography |publisher=Tiscali.co.uk |date=2012-07-23 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} In June 1999, at the Montgomery Theater in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], [[California]], Primich undertook a performance and series of workshops with [[Howard Levy]], [[Magic Dick]], Gary Smith, [[Lee Oskar]], [[Jerry Portnoy]], and [[Andy Santana]].[http://www.harmonicamasterclass.com/garciabio.htm ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} He was inducted in the Austin Music Hall of Fame. In September 2007, Primich died at his home in Austin, at the age of 49, of acute heroin intoxication.{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/column?oid=oid%3A554284 |title=Austin News, Events, Restaurants, Music |publisher=The Austin Chronicle |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==Discography== *''Gary Primich'' (1991) - Amazing *''My Pleasure'' (1992) - Amazing *''Hot Harp Blues'' (1993) - Amazing *''Travelin' Mood'' (1994) - [[Flying Fish Records|Flying Fish]] *''Mr. Freeze'' (1995) - Flying Fish *''Company Man'' (1997) - [[Black Top Records|Black Top]] *''Botheration'' (1999) - Black Top *''Dog House Music'' (2002) - Antone's *''Ridin' the Darkhorse'' (2006) - Electro-Fi{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gary-primich-mn0000800271/discography |title=Gary Primich | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} *''Just a Little Bit More ... with Omar Dykes'' (2012) - Old Pal Records ==See also== *[[List of electric blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonicists]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p115857/biography|pure_url=yes}} Biography] at [[Allmusic]] *[http://www.nme.com/artists/gary-primich Photographs and videos at NME.com] *[http://www.garyprimich.com Official Site] {{Authority control|VIAF=79764138}} {{Persondata | NAME =Primich, Gary | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player, singer, guitarist and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH =April 20, 1958 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | DATE OF DEATH =September 23, 2007 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Primich, Gary}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Illinois]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Illinois]] [[Category:People from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:Deaths by heroin overdose in the United States]]
